summary: WSJ editors pick the best photos of the year organized by category, date and location. These photos represent the key moments and defining images of the news in 2010.

summary: Devin Harris scored 22 points and Brook Lopez added 16 in the win.

summary: What's News: World-Wide for December 20, 2010.

headline: Delhi Braces for Art Tiger Attack
summary: Campaigning for tiger rights is about to take an artistic turn with an initiative called 'Artiger,' which will see 56 life-size sculptures planted in 50 locations across Delhi starting next week. Some snapshots.

headline: H-P Amps Up Cisco Sales Rivalry
summary: The rivalry between Hewlett-Packard and Cisco Systems, once close-knit partners, is growing fierce. H-P on Monday offered customers 20% off certain networking gear for quitting Cisco products.

headline: AmEx Slide Weighs on Dow
summary: Stocks rose modestly as traders weighed positive economic signals against worries about debt problems in the U.S. and abroad.

headline: Massey Board Weighing at Least Two Offers
summary: Massey Energy's board is weighing more than two bids from potential buyers but hasn't decided to start a formal auction process.

headline: Officials Point to Suicide in Banker's Death
summary: Authorities investigating the death of David Widlak, chief executive of Community Central Bank in Mount Clemens, Mich., said they believe it is likely that he killed himself but cannot rule out homicide.

headline: U.S. Mint Director to Leave for Private Sector
summary: U.S. Mint Director Edmund C. Moy is set to depart for a private-sector job next month.

headline: Ozawa Rejects Kan's Request on Panel
summary: Strife within Japan's ruling party escalated after a scandal-tainted party heavyweight rejected a request from the prime minister to appear before an ethics panel.

headline: U.S. Mine Accidents Killed 48 in Year
summary: The Massey Energy Co. accident in April that claimed the lives of 29 miners made this the deadliest year for U.S. coal miners in nearly two decades, with 48 workers killed in accidents at mines through Monday.

headline: A Sporting Chance
summary: None

headline: Adobe Swings to Profit
summary: Adobe swung to a fiscal fourth-quarter profit, as strong product sales boosted revenue.

headline: Russian Firms Set Potash Deal
summary: Russian potash fertilizer producers Uralkali and Silvinit announced a long-awaited merger, which will create a company with a market capitalization of about $24 billion.

headline: Paul Levy: Dreaming of a Meatless Christmas
summary: Are some aggressive vegetarians suffering a psychosexual wound?

headline: Russia Warns Against START Changes
summary: Russia's Foreign Minister Monday warned that any changes to a nuclear-weapons-reduction treaty now facing a tough ratification vote in the U.S. Senate could kill the pact.

headline: Vinashin Payment Deadline Looms
summary: Vietnam's beleaguered state-run shipbuilder Vinashin said it hasn't yet reached a deal with creditors to delay a $60 million debt repayment.

headline: SEC Renews Push for Wiretaps in Galleon Case
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission is making a renewed push for copies of wiretapped conversations from Galleon Group founder Raj Rajaratnam's criminal insider-trading case.

headline: Financial Briefing Book: Dec. 21
summary: Financial Briefing Book: Dec. 21

headline: Opulent Asian Fusion
summary: SHO Shaun Hergatt, an Asian fusion restaurant in the heart of the Financial District, brings opulence to an area that's still trying to find its footing since the downturn.

headline: Pfizer Recalls 19,000 Lipitor Bottles
summary: Pfizer plans to recall about 19,000 bottles of its cholesterol-lowering drug Lipitor in the U.S., marking the fourth such recall since August due to odor complaints.

headline: Weathering the Storm: the Top 5 Cities for Finance
summary: The U.S. finance industry has shed 419,000 jobs since Lehman went bust, but the crisis hit a few cities like Miami and Detroit particularly hard. Meanwhile, some metro areas, including Phoenix and St. Louis, maintained relatively robust ranks of bankers and investors.

headline: Icahn Builds Stake in Chesapeake Energy
summary: Billionaire activist investor Carl Icahn has built up a 5.8% stake in Chesapeake Energy Corp., according to a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's pictures, Belarusians protest a presidential election, the Eagles rally to beat the Giants, a U.S. tourist is killed in Israel and more.

headline: Treasurys Rally Loses Steam
summary: The U.S. government-bond market got off to a strong start as the Federal Reserve stepped in to buy Treasurys, but it faded in the afternoon to end New York trading unchanged to a tad higher.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: Oil Climbs 79 Cents
summary: Cold weather across the Northern Hemisphere and a pipeline explosion in Mexico helped pushed oil-futures prices higher.

headline: Senators Plan Debt-Reduction Bill
summary: Sens. Saxby Chambliss and Mark Warner said they would introduce legislation early next year that mirrors the recent report by the White House's debt-reduction panel, in an effort to promote a conversation on the country's fiscal problems.

headline: Gold Gains $6.90 on Korea, Euro Tensions
summary: Gold futures gained $6.90 a troy ounce to $1,385.50, supported by renewed European debt worries and tensions in the Korean peninsula.

headline: Ex-William Morris CEO Sues Starr, Lawyer
summary: The former chief executive of talent agency William Morris sued ex-New York money manager Kenneth Starr and his lawyer on Monday for allegedly misappropriating $2 million he entrusted to Mr. Starr.

headline: Rachel Marsden: Silvio Berlusconi's Virtue
summary: The only people in Italian politics who are worse than the prime minister are. . . everyone else.

headline: EPA Puts Some Greenhouse-Gas Rules on Hold
summary: The Obama administration, facing complaints from businesses, said it would delay until as late as 2014 a measure to force companies to reveal the amount of fuel and solvents associated with greenhouse-gas emissions.

headline: Hypermarcas Buys Mantecorp
summary: Brazilian consumer-products maker Hypermarcas agreed to buy Mantecorp, a pharmaceutical company, for about $1.47 billion.

headline: Big Dynegy Holder Opposes Icahn-Backed Buyout Bid
summary: Seneca Capital, which holds a 12% stake in Dynegy, said it opposes an Icahn-backed company's $5.50-a-share bid to take the power generator private, and urged shareholders not to tender their shares.

headline: J.P. Morgan Buys U.K. Property
summary: J.P. Morgan Chase has bought two buildings in London, a sign the U.S. bank isn't fazed by new rules that make it more expensive to operate in the U.K.

headline: Czech Rulers Face Confidence Vote
summary: The fate of the Czech government hangs in the balance after it failed to secure the support of a coalition partner it needs to survive a vote of confidence over a corruption scandal.

headline: LSE Expects Boost in IPO Pipeline
summary: London Stock Exchange Group expects a healthier pipeline of initial public offerings next year, with its secondary market for small and midsize companies playing a more important role.

headline: OptionsXpress Defends Handling of Special Dividend
summary: OptionsXpress's chief executive said the company followed all the required procedures for a big special dividend whose rules turned out to confuse many investors.

headline: RBS Seeks to Pay Cash Bonuses
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland is in talks with U.K. Financial Investments to allow the U.K. bank to award cash bonuses to employees for 2010, but cap it at £50,000, a person familiar with the situation said.

headline: AEP Taps New President
summary: American Electric Power. tapped Nicholas K. Akins, the head of its power generation activity, as the utility's new president, effective Jan. 1.

headline: Numbers Don't Ring Up for VimpelCom Deal
summary: In voting against a VimpelCom-Weather Investments deal, Telenor is acting rationally in the absence of a renegotiation on price.

headline: Buckeye Partners Seeks Bahamas Oil Stake
summary: Petroleum distributor Buckeye Partners LP said it will buy an 80% interest in Bahamas Oil Refining Co. from private-equity firm First Reserve Corp. for $1.36 billion.

headline: MoneyGram International, Alliance Bancorp Inc. of Pennsylvania: Biggest Price Gainers (MGI, ALLB)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Raytheon to Buy Applied Signal
summary: Defense contractor Raytheon will pay about $490 million to buy intelligence- and reconnaissance-products company Applied Signal Technology.

headline: Italy Shines as European Stocks Gain
summary: European stocks rose, with the Italian market posting particularly strong gains, while airlines and retailers fell on fears of lost business caused by the severe winter weather.

headline: Gartmore Falls on Henderson Approach
summary: Shares in Gartmore Group fell sharply on news that the U.K. fund manager is considering a takeover proposal from local rival Henderson Group at a discount to its recent share price.

headline: Elephants Out of the Gate
summary: JOHN FUND ON THE TRAIL  Last week brought a flurry of announcements for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination that will start flushing candidates out of their protective cover.

headline: Former OCC Chief Dugan Rejoins Covington & Burling
summary: John Dugan, who was the top regulator for some of the U.S.'s biggest banks, is returning to law firm Covington & Burling to lead the division representing such firms before regulators and Congress.

headline: EarthLink to Buy One Communications
summary: EarthLink agreed to acquire privately held One Communications in a deal valued at $370 million.

headline: Boeing Plans to Boost 777 Production
summary: Boeing announced plans to again boost production of its 777 aircraft, the latest sign of increasing demand in the airplane industry.

headline: Medtronic CEO to Retire in April
summary: Medtronic said its chairman and chief executive, William A. Hawkins, will retire in April, the end of the company's current fiscal year.

headline: Noble to Buy Two Sugar Mills From Brazil's Cerradinho
summary: Noble Group said it will acquire two sugar mills from Brazilian ethanol producer Grupo Cerradinho for $950 million.

headline: Community Health to Nominate Directors for Tenet Board
summary: Community Health Systems said it plans to nominate directors for election to Tenet Healthcare's board, signaling the start of a proxy fight as Community continues to try to buy Tenet.

headline: ECB Warns Ireland on Legislation
summary: The European Central Bank warned Ireland that proposed legislation revamping the country's financial system could threaten some of the ECB's operations, and pressed Irish officials for assurances that the central bank's collateral rights will be protected.

headline: S&P Proposes Changes to Muni Note Ratings
summary: Standard & Poor's is seeking comment on proposed revisions to ratings on so-called bond anticipation notes sold by many state and local governments.

headline: Euro-Zone Consumer Confidence Drops
summary: Consumer confidence in the euro zone deteriorated unexpectedly in December as several of the single currency area's smaller states continued to struggle with severe debt problems.

headline: Australia: $40 Billion Broadband Plan is Viable
summary: A controversial plan to invest roughly $40 billion for a high-speed Internet network across Australia will be profitable, the government said, dismissing criticism that the project is a waste of the windfall from the nation's resources boom.

headline: Election in Belarus
summary: Belarussian President Alexander Lukashenko was declared re-elected to a fourth term by a landslide Monday, after a thousands-strong protest against alleged large-scale electoral fraud was violently broken up by riot police Sunday evening.

headline: Asia Falls on Korea Worries
summary: Asian markets ended broadly lower Monday after a volatile session that was dominated by geopolitical tensions on the Korean peninsula. The Kopsi ended 0.3% lower.

headline: Varnholt Turns Against the Tide
summary: The chief investment officer of Sarasin Bank sees wealth in water investments.

headline: Moody's Cuts Irish Banks' Ratings
summary: Moody's cut its ratings on several major Irish banks days after it slashed the country's sovereign-debt ratings by five notches.

headline: Boom Bolsters Palestinian Statehood
summary: Amid gloomy peace prospects with Israel, an economic boom in Ramallah, West Bank, has emboldened proponents of an independent Palestinian state. But obstacles remain.

headline: Novartis Invests $500 Million in Russia
summary: Novartis said it will invest around $500 million in Russia over the next five years amid efforts to better tap into one of the world's fastest growing emerging markets.

headline: U.K. Mortgage Growth Slows
summary: U.K. gross mortgage lending grew at a slower pace in November from October, and at the slowest November pace since 2000 as part of a traditional seasonal slowdown in the housing market.

headline: Japanese Yields Soften
summary: Japanese government bond yields eased Monday and could continue easing through the end of the year.

headline: CDB Ventures Into Private Equity
summary: China Development Bank expects to close the first round of funding for its private-equity fund-of-funds by the end of this month, as the state-owned lender expands its commercial efforts.

headline: Firing Drill Increases Korea Tensions
summary: South Korea test-fired artillery from an island North Korea attacked last month, defying North Korean threats of another attack and asserting its rights in a maritime area it has controlled since the Korean War of the 1950s.

headline: Claris Shares Make Weak Debut
summary: India's Claris Lifesciences made a weak stock market debut, dragged down by concerns over a ban on one of its manufacturing facilities by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for failure to meet some quality standards.

headline: OECD Backs Spain's Deficit Cuts
summary: The OECD said Spain's budget deficit reduction plan "seems appropriate," but urged the country to push forward with changes to its banking sector, labor laws and to rules on regional-government expenditure.

headline: After Lean Years, Darden Looks to Feast
summary: Restaurant sales are finally picking up after a rough patch. That should bode well for Darden Restaurants' results.

headline: Peugeot: China Sales to Surpass France
summary: French auto maker Peugeot is likely to sell more cars in China's booming market than in its home market by around 2015, a forecast that underscores China's rapidly expanding market.

headline: Sasol Invests $1 Billion in Canadian Gas
summary: Sasol, the world's largest producer of motor fuels from coal, said it's buying half of Talisman Energy's Farrell Creek shale-gas assets in British Columbia for $1.04 billion, significantly boosting its natural gas resources.

headline: Sachin Makes History
summary: India's Sachin Tendulkar set a world record by becoming the first batsman to make 50 Test centuries -- the latest in a string of achievements this year, seen as the best in his career. Some photos.

headline: Perpetual, KKR Fail to Reach Deal
summary: Australian fund manager Perpetual Ltd. and U.S.-based private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts ended takeover talks after failing to reach a deal, sending Perpetual's stock down 14% though analysts said another suitor was likely to emerge.

headline: Sistema Shyam Expects Russia Investment Next Quarter
summary: Sistema Shyam Teleservices said it expects the Russian government's investment of around $600 million to come through in the January-March quarter, giving the mobile operator much-needed funds to expand its operations in India.

headline: German Producer Prices Rise
summary: Producer prices in Germany continued to rise in November, with energy and consumer goods prices leading the way.

headline: Short-Term Savings Option: Bond Funds
summary: Investors have lately been piling into short-term bonds funds amid uncertainty over long-term interest rates. These can often be a better deal than fixed deposits, says Shefali Anand, India personal finance writer.

headline: CBI Sends Notice to Raja for Questioning
summary: India's federal investigation agency served a notice on former telecommunications minister, Andimuthu Raja, as part of its ongoing probe into the alleged irregularities in allotment of telecom licenses.

headline: LG Seeks Turnaround With Investment in Electronics
summary: South Korea's LG Group will spend nearly 70% of its planned investment next year in beefing up its electronics businesses, including smartphones, tablet computers and advanced flat panels.

headline: Sony Aims to Boost TV Sales
summary: A Sony Corp. executive said Monday that the consumer electronics maker is targeting an increase in television sales in the next fiscal year as it looks to return its struggling TV unit to profitability.

headline: Emanuel's Mayoral Campaign Enlists Legal Heavyweights
summary: Rahm Emanuel's campaign filed a friend of the court brief on Saturday signed by a team of Chicago legal heavyweights arguing that Mr. Emanuel shouldn't be kicked off the mayoral ballot.

headline: My Two Cents: Larry King Says Goodbye
summary: An unworthy homage to Larry King's late, beloved USA Today column.

headline: As Holiday Nears, Cash Registers Sing
summary: In the countdown to Christmas, packed malls and long checkout lines indicate that U.S.  consumers have been willing to come out and spend, at least when retailers offered deep bargains.

headline: The Wind Subsidy Bubble
summary: Green pork should be a GOP budget target.

headline: My Vacation in Chernobyl
summary: Ukraine's government wants to turn the site of the world's worst nuclear accident into a tourism hot spot. The school essays aren't far behind, in Reply to All.

headline: Smartphone Marketers Plan Privacy Rules
summary: Facing growing public concern about privacy breaches, a lobby representing mobile-phone advertisers and publishers called for guidelines to better protect smartphone users from intrusive tracking technologies.

headline: States Weigh More Rules for Dog Breeders
summary: Authorities in Oklahoma and Missouri, the nation's top two puppy-producing states, are moving to impose tough new regulations on dog breeders. The regulations aim to give dogs more space, more exercise and more regular contact with caretakers.

headline: Winter Surfing A Leap of Faith
summary: Surfers have been subjecting themselves to the Rockaway Beach winters for as long as any local can recall. "If you don't surf in the winter in New York, you don't surf," one said.

headline: Ask Next: Reversing Course With Roth IRAs
summary: Rules for recharacterizations, calculating tax liabilities, and paying back benefits.

headline: Rebuilding in the City
summary: Singer Aaron Neville navigates the good times and the bad.

headline: O'Grady: WikiLeaks, Honduras and the U.S.
summary: Released cables make it clear that the U.S. knew Manuel Zelaya was a threat to democracy in Honduras.

headline: Treatments for Enlarged Veins in Face
summary: In Aches & Claims, Laura Johannes examines new treatments and products aimed at eliminating or reducing the prominence of spider veins—enlarged blood vessels near the surface of the skin on the face.

headline: The Nurses Union Is Unhappy With Gov. Tim Pawlenty
summary: Minnesota Gov. Tim Pawlenty's "Government Unions vs. Taxpayers" (op-ed, Dec. 13) is filled with the political rhetoric that our soon-to-be-former governor has been using to start his 2012 presidential bid, instead of serving the people of Minnesota.

headline: U.S. Hits Toyota With Fine on Lapses
summary: The Obama administration slapped Toyota with $32.4 million in civil penalties, the maximum allowed by law, for failing to properly disclose what it knew about safety defects linked to recalls of millions of vehicles last year and earlier this year.

headline: What's Fair About Confiscating Honestly Gained Money?
summary: Regarding William McGurn's "'Billionaires On the Warpath'?" (Main Street, Dec. 14): Leftists like Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders regularly turn reality on its head in their claim to the moral high ground, and it's about time they get called on it.

headline: U.S. Sanctions Ivory Coast Leader
summary: The U.N. extended its peacekeeping mission in Ivory Coast and the U.S. announced a travel ban on President Laurent Gbagbo, whose refusal to concede electoral defeat has plunged the West African nation into new violence.

headline: Total, Suncor Set Oil-Sands Alliance
summary: French oil major Total said its Canadian subsidiary will pay Suncor Energy $1.74 billion to form a strategic alliance pooling their interests in several oil sands projects in Canada.

headline: Senate Poised to Vote on Funding Bill
summary: The Senate moved ahead Sunday night on a deal to fund the federal government through March 4, setting the stage for a budget fight early next year, when Republicans will wield more power in Washington.

headline: The Best In... Staying Fit
summary: How to take charge of your health in the face of "ageism" in medicine, and where to find evidence-based information about alternative medicine.

headline: Cuts Threaten Thriving Detroit Community
summary: Auto-plant tax revenue has helped power Hamtramck, Mich., a working-class city of 22,000 for years, but a halt to this stream of cash amid a dispute with neighboring Detroit is driving the town to the brink.

headline: Protesters at Met Rally for Artwork
summary: Several hundred people gathered at the Metropolitan Museum of Art to protest the recent decision by the Smithsonian to remove a contentious video from a current exhibit at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington, D.C.

headline: Tech Revival Lifts Silicon Valley
summary: As California's $1.9 trillion economy struggles, the technology-rich Silicon Valley in the northern part of the state is experiencing a revival.

headline: An Essential Cheesemonger
summary: While our fear of cheese abates with age, it never vanishes completely (for Ralph Gardner, at least). Which is why the cheesemonger occupies such a pivotal role in the culinary pantheon.

headline: Iraqi Prime Minister Presents Cabinet
summary: Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki presented his cabinet lineup to parliament, taking the first major concrete step toward ending a political crisis that consumed the country for more than nine months.

headline: Russia's Khodorkovsky Discount
summary: The judgment for or against jailed tycoon Mikhail Khodorkovsky in a Moscow court later this month will be a historic one for Russia. Do investors care?

headline: Presbyterians (USA) Aren't Anti-Israel
summary: Marvin Hier and Abraham Cooper's "Presbyterians Against Israel" (Houses of Worship, Dec. 3) is misleading. The Presbyterian Church (USA) was not among those who greeted with "accolades" the controversial Kairos Palestine Document.

headline: Good Year Isn't Enough to Save Some Deals
summary: This has been a good year for values in New York's office building market. But the rising tide still hasn't been enough to save the deals that were launched at the top of the market.

headline: FDA to Probe J&J's Rolaids Contractor
summary: The incoming chairman of a committee probing J&J's product recalls has asked regulators to look into the use of a contract manufacturer to make Rolaids antacids that were recalled for quality problems.

headline: City Settles Discrimination Claim
summary: New York City gave $40,000 to an Orthodox Jewish nurse to settle a discrimination claim filed after a city hospital withdrew a job offer because she couldn't work on the Sabbath.

headline: Van, Stolen in '74, Returns Home With a Little Help From Its Friends
summary: Last Christmas, Michele "Mikey" Carlson Squires' middle son, Matt, gave her a toy Volkswagen van, just like the blue-and-white hippie mobile stolen from her in 1974. This year, Ms. Squires has her bus back just in time for Christmas.

headline: Fortune Swings to Australia
summary: Mitchell Johnson reignited the Ashes with a breathtaking display of bowling in the third Test in Perth, taking nine wickets as Australia squared the series at 1-1 with two games to play.

headline: Elle Is Question Mark in Hachette Talks
summary: Lagardère's talks to sell some or all of its Hachette international magazines to Hearst hinge largely on a single question: How much of Elle are the French willing to surrender?

headline: Ernst & Young Faces Fraud Charges
summary: New York prosecutors are poised to file civil fraud charges against Ernst & Young for its alleged role in the collapse of Lehman Brothers.

headline: Congress, SEC Hit Stocks Made in China
summary: The SEC has begun a crackdown on the practices of the "reverse takeover" market for Chinese stock listings, looking into how U.S. accountants, lawyers, and bankers have helped bring Chinese companies to the U.S. market.

summary: Social networking surges in the 50-plus crowd; a valuable resource for experienced and wannabe chefs.

headline: Schwimmer's Night With the Orchestra
summary: The actor and his photographer wife do double-duty at a benefit concert featuring the Salomé Chamber Orchestra.

headline: Health Matters: Circulation Solutions
summary: Varicose veins can be disabling, but new remedies are easing removal.

headline: Richard Haass: Let's Un-Surge in Afghanistan
summary: The current policy is diverting scarce military resources when threats like Iran and North Korea loom. We can prevent the return of al Qaeda with far fewer troops.

headline: World Watch
summary: Here is a selection of news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: U.S.-Canada Near Border-Security Deal
summary: The U.S. and Canada are in the final stages of hammering out a broad pact on border security that could be unveiled within the next several weeks.

headline: The Doctor's Dog Will See You Now
summary: A growing number of therapists are using "canine assistants" in their practices. Dogs are a nonjudgmental presence when patients get emotional or need the calming effect of petting an animal.

headline: Parlor Closings Threaten  Track
summary: The closure of New York City's Off Track Betting parlors has threatened the survival of the Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens just as Genting Bhd. has begun construction of the city's first legal gaming parlor next door.

headline: Guatemala Declares a State of Siege
summary: The Guatemalan government declared a state of siege in a province it said has become overrun by a Mexican drug-trafficking group, the latest sign that Mexico's powerful cartels have extended their reach into foreign lands.

headline: Russia's Medvedev in Indian Arms Push
summary: Russian President Dmitry Medvedev arrives Tuesday in India on a two-day trip aimed at solidifying Moscow's role as New Delhi's largest arms supplier in the face of increased competition from the United States and Europe.

headline: Moving to Argentina
summary: A California couple's serendipitous exposure to Buenos Aires led them to explore the country, and eventually buy a vineyard and start a new life in the city of Mendoza.

headline: Crovitz: E-Seuss: Be Glad, Not Sad or Mad
summary: Children's books are especially suited for the iPad.

headline: U.S. Mounts Rare-Earth Challenge
summary: Responding to China's recent squeeze on the global supply of rare earths, a U.S. company plans to reopen its mine that produces the unusual metals, which are critical to making high-tech products.

summary: Where to find advice on living outside the U.S., and why hostels aren't just for backpacking students.

headline: Iran Cuts Fuel Subsidy
summary: Iran cut food and fuel subsidies, triggering a rush by drivers to fill up their tanks ahead of a fourfold increase in gas prices. Witnesses reported a heavy security presence throughout big cities.

headline: Waterfront Marbella Home
summary: This four-floor residence in the Costa del Sol was originally owned by Spain's most famous flamenco dancer and choreographer Antonio Ruiz Soler, also known as "Antonio el Bailarin."

headline: MSG President 'Adopts' for Christmas
summary: Hank Ratner launched the Garden of Dreams Foundation four years ago in an effort to combine the considerable power of some of the company's biggest pieces into one charitable endeavor.

headline: Europe's Single Bailout Zone
summary: The moves toward a fiscal union mean German taxpayers have become the lenders of last resort.

summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: Sadanand Dhume: What Terrorizes India?
summary: The notion that radical Hinduism is more of a threat to India than radical Islam is ludicrous.

headline: UConn Effortlessly Makes History
summary: UConn overpowered Ohio State, 81-50, to stake their claim to history in front of a 15,232 fans, the second-largest recorded crowd for women's college basketball at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Photos Deepen 'Grim Sleeper' Mystery
summary: Police may be rethinking the theory that the alleged "Grim Sleeper" once took a 14-year break between killings, as they released 180 photos they said they found at his house.

headline: John Lee: China's National Insecurity
summary: Beijing sees Liu Xiaobo's Nobel Peace Prize as part of an international strategy to contain China's rise.

headline: The Best In…Financing Your Future
summary: Preparing for medical bills and finding help on IRA questions.

headline: Euro Zone's Song of Indecision
summary: The tune "Undecided," written more than 60 years before the euro was launched, should be the theme song of the eurocracy. It certainly is a better description of the state of play than the official EU anthem, "Ode To Joy."

headline: Snow, Ice Ground Flights Across Europe
summary: Travel remained snarled across Europe as major airports faced a third day of delays and cancellations that stranded almost one million passengers.
